column1: Stringfellow allows the country tendencies that have always lurked in his

Frosting on the Beater.
""This One's on You"" pulls back the reins and turns back the clock to roughly the
time when Bernie Leadon was still in the Eagles.  One of the Posies' main
strengths was always the harmonies of Auer and Stringfellow.  Here
Stringfellow simply layers his own voice and while this works well enough

lacking on Touched. On his own
column2: Stringfellow's voice also has a somewhat

column1: alarming tendency to sound like Timothy B. Schmidt on the high notes

and well-performed
column3: but a closer listen reveals several

column1: piano and Rhodes tracks filling out the background

""Uniforms"" begins over a bed of cello and violin
pop full of cleanly strummed guitars
column3: and even a bit of distant

column1: clip-clop percussion nicked straight from Pet Sounds. Atmospheric synths

column2: only to give way to a piano interlude that lays the

column1: groundwork for the last few verses.  The rhythm pushes forward harder than before

""Sparrow"" is the best of an impressive quartet of classic power-pop songs with

column1: instrumental bridge.  The Hammond-soaked ""Reveal Love"" comes down a notch

It's followed by ""Fireflies

It's an orgy-- something that may not have been designed for mass consumption

incestuous marriages; that the kids who are voluntarily dropping out of the

As each day passes
column2: it becomes more and more difficult to write a truly gratifying

column1: pop song. Part of the pop equation relies on a sense of spontaneity that has
become increasingly elusive as listeners have now had
years to construct an emotional immunity to the same unvarying formula. There
are always those who will invert the standard for successful songwriting
the accessibility to the less daring. Then there are those who acknowledge the
inescapable grasp and scope of their musical heritage and imbue their own music
with enough inventiveness to endure repeated discriminating listens.
Unfortunately
column2: many seemingly creative bands merely stumble upon whatever unique

column1: sonic deviations earmark their respective ""sound"" and
infuse it with every damn Beatles/Chuck Berry regurgitation they write. So it
should be said that while an original technique is an occasional indicator of
true talent (i.e. Phil Elvrum and his affinity for right/left channel panning
guitars) true judgment should be reserved for the frequency in which you actually
listen to the artist's recorded output. This is the best way to delineate between
talent and plain sticktuitiveness. So what do you do with all those outstanding
songs mired in between album-filler and the token ballad attempt? You make a mix
tape.
Orion Walker expresses his love of mix tapes in the liner notes of the soundtrack
to his film
column2: Dean Quixote. ""There's a lot of great music being made... but

column1: you'll never hear this music unless you look for it. Or unless you're lucky
enough to have a friend that makes you a mix tape..."" Indeed
to be a man of sage-like advice and the psychedelic murmuring of his mix tape
to us
column3: only reinforces the notion that he's a thinking man's man

column1: and his taste is nigh impeccable.
The album commences with the Olivia Tremor Control's ""Jumping Fences"" which
after nearly five years
column2: still evokes the same paradoxical euphoric dystopia as

column1: it did on Dusk at Cubist Castle. There is no conceptual analysis of
the modern pop song to be found
column2: as on Black Foliage-- just Will Cullen

column1: Hart and Bill Doss stretching their comparative musical muscles and setting the
ambience for the vast majority of the record.
Elephant Six dignitary Robert Schneider seems to pop up randomly throughout the
course of the album. His band
the inclusion of ""What Happened Then"" from the hit-and-miss <i>Discovery of a
World Inside the Moone
column2: and his Orchestre Fantastique offer up the film's

column1: theme
incidental music for 70s educational programming
column2: but within the context of the

column1: album
column2: its breeziness is easily overlooked-- especially when compared to the

column1: Beachwood Sparks' ""This is What It Feels Like (Alt. Version)."" Both of these
tracks
column2: which would normally undergo a far more jaded critical knife

column1: provide a fair definition for the album: a group of artists offering their
winning interpretations of the ""archetypal pop song.""
The Minders turn out a piece that's not entirely dissimilar from what Nick Drake's
instrumental ""Bryter Layter"" would sound like if interpreted as elevator music
and Spink (whose name should really be changed if they wish to gain an ounce of
respect) cover the Palace Brothers' classic ""New Partner."" Elsewhere
stay around just long enough to infect your blood with the catchy-as-all-hell
""Hot Black Silk."" Though it may be impossible for Jason Molina to escape the
Will Oldham comparisons
column2: he shows here that he has the range (musically and

column1: vocally) to transcend a few of those stylistic similarities.
The remainder of the album is similarly engaging. Robert Pollard
supposedly close friends with Walker
column2: appears in the film and donates the

column1: underrated gem ""If We Wait"" from the generous ten-song Sunfish Holy Breakfast
EP.  And
column2: like such revivalist luminaries as Goldfrapp and the Squirrel Nut

column1: Zippers in their more sultry moments
column2: Crystal Keith and Kim Fox come to the

column1: radical conclusion that the seduction of lounge music didn't die in the 40s

column2: ""O What a Noble Mind Is Here Overthrown.""

column1: I'm glad to say that I haven't seen Dean Quixote. Hearing these songs free
of their intended context seems to have nourished the area of my brain that would
have been deprived of stimulation had I watched this film at the local art house.
So I'm taking the purist's route. The visualizations I've conjured up are more
fantastic than anything that can be committed to celluloid. Life just can't be
contained in 24-frames-a-second
column2: and rather than have the film inspire the

column1: soundtrack
column2: I've allowed the music to catalyze my generally dormant creativity.

column1: The only flaw in my plan: my expectations for the actual film have far exceeded

the very constraints of cinema. This soundtrack has ruined it all for me.

When Appleseed Cast released The End of the Ring Wars three years ago
they were the embodiment of late 90s emo-rock
that displayed the extent of their ambition.  The problem was
seemed uncontrolled
column2: and the album came off like an emotional effigy of the

column1: band's aspirations which their experience wasn't quite capable of making fully
palpable. Last year's Mare Vitalis found them reigning in their sound
and softening the edges while simultaneously beginning to experiment with new
textures.  The album ended with an extended untitled track of feedback and guitar
loops that no one could have predicted was the fuse to what was coming next.
Low Level Owl is a supernova and a full redefinition of the band
sprawling two-disc monster that redirects their ambition from the emotional
release of their earlier albums into the meticulous conceptions crafted through
endless hours of studio time.  Overhauling their sound and incorporating a wide
mélange of styles
column2: Low Level Owl goes a long way towards emasculating any

column1: of their previous hardcore influences by injecting a thoughtful
jangle and winsome vocals and harmonies.  The result is a mix of elements

shimmering Stone Roses psychedelia knitted together with the conviction and
energetic drumming of the early U2
column2: all draped over a monolithic prog-rock

column1: conceptual framework.
The technical execution throughout the album is flawless.  The rock tracks are
spread evenly across both Low Level Owl discs (which are available
separately-- Use Your Illusion-style-- presumably so as to not overwhelm
listeners) and are interspersed with instrumental and ambient tracks that act as
connective tissue.  Josh Baruth's fantastic drumming is placed in the front of
the mix and propels all of the traditional songs.  Each of the tracks are awash
in keyboards with the vocals generally lying low in the mix
difficult to decipher.  These are the only constants through the entire work as
Appleseed Cast takes you on a tour through most of the highlights of 90s pop and
rock.
Both albums are balanced

""They were crazy; we were all crazy-- we had a code of honor that said: no

column1: compromises; we could do absolutely what we feel like with no respect for
anybody and no consideration of any consequences no matter what.""
-- Jean-Hervé Peron
This was the Faust way; a band whose members may never have considered what kind
of influence they would have on the future of rock and shock and everything in
decent civilization.  And anyone who hears them either understands Peron's code
or goes home disappointed (or frustratingly off-put) with the music.  For me
one of the great things about many of the classic Krautrock bands is their
familial ethics
column2: wherein the individual only exists in relation to the whole

column1: and the end result is always more than the sum of the parts.  Faust was communal
like that
Interestingly
column2: thirty years of rumination on what possible inspiration (besides

column1: the drugs
column2: of course) might have pushed Faust to make such wonderful noise has

column1: left very little concrete information.  We know that they were six strong
five
column2: and that they had something of a guardian angel watching over them and

column1: providing them with the bare necessities-- food
to their record company-- in Uwe Nettlebeck.  We know that they worked and lived
in a small
column2: abandoned schoolhouse in Wümme for a time
column3: and that most of what came

column1: out of that schoolhouse gave the alternative education to innocent and willing
students everywhere.
One thing we don't know is exactly how it all came to pass in Wümme.  Jean-Hervé
Peron and the rest of the remaining members (including Nettlebeck and engineer
Kurt Graupner) have all given interviews detailing what went down in during those
sessions
column2: and relatively insignificant details have come out over time: most of

column1: the music was recorded on eight-track; the group would often spend days in one
room recording without a producer to tell them if they were on to something; they
often built pieces up like parts of chain because they'd recorded so many
disparate elements at different times.  When I read these things
mostly technical revelations
column2: but nothing ever tells me about the impetus of the

column1: music. Where did it come from?
So
column2: Julian Cope calls Faust the most ""mythical"" of the original Krautrock bands

I feel sorry for bands who have to compete with critics' unrealized expectations.
We saw what Rome (Written Upside Down) did for Les Savy Fav's Go Forth
and we're not happy.  What would have otherwise been a rather fulfilling
full-length seemed to lack the innovation that was promised by the group's
tour-de-force EP. I certainly don't want to sentence And You Will Know Us by the
Trail of Dead to this fate-- expectations easily get out of hand and can quickly
become insurmountable-- but it appears that they've brought it on themselves.
Why else would they release this seemingly innocuous collection of scrawling
post-punk?
The band's newly honed songwriting skills become immediately apparent on the
disc's first track
column3: the Trail of Dead are still having

column1: a great time attempting to recreate the Daydream Nation experience
here
column2: they're finally pulling it off with enough intensity to convince you that

column1: the sound still has some uncharted ground to be covered.  That having been said
the new EP expands their once-limited musical vocabulary to convey such
previously foreign topics as happiness and sanguinity.  And the lyrics
still predominantly angstful
column2: have matured to the point of potency and

column1: quotability.  Here's a slice for you: ""It's okay
column2: I'm a saint/ I forgave your

column1: mistakes.""  Nevermind that Kevin Allen's voice sounds more like Thurston Moore
than ever.
All too often
column2: artists evolve sonically while choosing to jettison the most

column1: effective nuances of their music. While I believe it's necessary for artists to
self-actualize
column2: it should be noted that they tend to alienate much of their

column1: fanbase in the process.  So
column2: there's something to be said for groups whose

column1: initial approach to writing consistently yields profound results.  Such is the
case with ""Blood Rites
column2: the EP's obligatory reflection on the essential formula

column1: of the Trail's previous outings. The recent popularity of such decidedly pubescent
groups as Slipknot and Papa Roach has made it harder for songs of this genre to
yield outstanding moments
column2: but the Trail of Dead manage to walk on thin ice

column1: without slipping
column2: leaving us with the same self-effacing freshness of Madonna

column1: (the album).
This disc marks the first appearance of material written under the wing of
Interscope Records. The production values are up and the sound has lost a bit
of the intimacy that was once an integral part of the group's records.  Of course
this all seems trivial when compared with the leaps made in style and ability.
Even the primarily ambient ""Blade Runner
off with a formerly unseen grace.  All told
column2: it seems that the Trail have carved

column1: themselves a comfortable niche in which they can feel free to explore
and bastardize their influences into hideous four-minute gems.
It's not easy to cut an ""essential"" EP and
column2: despite the quality of the material

column1: and the consumer-friendly price
the Archers of Loaf's Vs. the Greatest of All Time
Each of those releases set a precedent by which the rest of their respective
artists' careers would be judged. And while Relative Ways is a departure
for the Trail of Dead
column2: it certainly doesn't mark a radical change in the band's

column2: when judged on its own terms

column1: well worth its price tag and
column3: hints at what could be achieved
